title: Fears of costlier imports water down oil stocks
text:
Shares of oil marketing companies saw sharp cuts on Wednesday amid speculation that China’s currency devaluation would make crude oil imports costlier, even as global crude prices continued their downward trajectory with supply exceeding demand.
The Hindustan Petroleum Corp (HPCL) scrip fell 7.56%, while Bharat Petroleum Corp (BPCL) and the country’s biggest state-run refiner, Indian Oil Corp (IOC), declined 6-78% each. Reliance Industries , the owner of world’s largest refining unit, also ended down 2.4% on the BSE, while Cairn India touched its 52-week low, pushing the gauge of oil and gas companies down nearly 3.5%.
Market experts and energy analysts highlighted a combination of factors for the decline in crude prices. Rupee’s depreciation against the dollar may escalate the cost of importing crude oil and negate the benefit of falling oil prices.
Oil accounts for one-third of India’s total imports, based on last year figures.
On Wednesday, the Indian rupee weakened to its weakest level in almost two years as China’s devaluation of the renminbi sparked concerns about China’s slowing economic growth and sluggish exports.
China’s move to devalue its currency for a second straight day also sent shockwaves through world stocks and currency markets.
Analysts said that traders booked profit — ahead of first quarter earnings — as shares of OMCs had risen sharply over the last 12 months, driven by deregulation of petrol and diesel prices and softer crude prices, allowing incremental marketing margins.
IOC will announce its Q1FY16 results on Thursday, while BPCL will announce its earnings on Friday. While HPCL reported better-than-expected earning, analysts do not foresee the performance to sustain. GRMs of state-owned refiners are expected to decline to sub-$6 per barrel after touching a peak of $8-9 levels.
